All 3 of those are open source, there isn't a vendor lock in from the perspective of the components, additionally in the server there are a number of extensions that are all open source.We are active contributors to the Postgres server as well as the HA solution. All of that is being done with the communities involved.  Effectively we are engaging with Open source communities and effectively packaging those products to enable user outcomes.Again, the operator/packaging is currently the only thing not open sourced.

Hi, I enabled "enable secure service instance credentials" in TAS mysql for VM tile, when binding the mysql service instance to application, it can correctly refer to the credhub url, however when I create service key, the password is in clear text, is it correct as designed?
3 replies
  2 years ago
Yes, the service key is for the developer who doesn't have access to TAS credhub to find the credential
  2 years ago
Just to be clear; service keys are still stored in CredHub. It's just that Cloud Foundry is rendering them for you when you ask for the information, as that's the purpose of service keys.It's the same way that Cloud Foundry (by default) interpolates credhub URLs when deploying an app, so that the app, also, sees the credentials in cleartext.But in both cases, the credentials are stored in a secure manner.
  2 years ago
OK, got it, Thanks a lot!

  2 years ago
@stevensonda in the upcoming 1.2.0 for TLS, users can specify a secret to use for TLS so that the ca can be verified. So the flow would be in k8s user creates a secret like below:
kubectl create secret generic TLS-SECRET-NAME \
  --type kubernetes.io/tls \
  --from-file=tls.crt=PATH-TO-CERTIFICATE \
  --from-file=tls.key=PATH-TO-PRIVATE-KEY \
  --from-file=ca.crt=PATH-TO-CERTIFICATE-AUTHORITY
and then we have a spec property that the user can set and kubectl apply <instance.yml>
spec:
  certificateSecretName: TLS-SECRET-NAME
you will not see the spec property in the version you have as it is 1.1.0 from pivnet. The doc as we have it suffices for 1.1.0If I remember TSMgr correctly, at least the tile version had a way to get certs from the tile that had the tls.key, tls.cert and tls.ca that we could put into a k8s secret that the postgres instance can use?The verification is then just a connection parameter in the cf cups command (edited)

  2 years ago
Hello - Could you share what is the DNS approach for the current tanzu mysql tile (multi-site) setup?
cc @bwebster (edited) 
1 reply
  2 years ago
What are you interested in regarding the DNS approach precisely?  Service discovery?  How database instances connect to each other?  How the apps connect to the database?At a high-level, the Tanzu MySQL tile’s architecture is described here:https://docs.pivotal.io/p-mysql/2-10/about-multi-site.htmlEssentially, in that architecture an app in each site connects “locally” to a mysql instance.   That mysql instance may be a primary or a read-replica.   If it’s a read-replica we proxy to the connection to the primary.We expect a user to implement a global / DNS load balancer in front of their applications in this case.If you have specific questions, I can try to answer those more precisely.

@channel VMware Tanzu SQL with Postgres for Kubernetes 1.2.0 is live on Tanzu Net! Kudos to @vmware-postgres-team and everyone else involved for getting this release out the door! Some of the major enhancements in this release are:
  • Enterprise Readiness: Making it easier to secure your connections to the database with TLS 
  • Improved security posture: Instances are created with ClusterIP instead of LoadBalancer by default
  • Try out new versions simply, without the need for a container registry 
  • One more sane default: Always get a writable connection
  • Helping with Oracle to PostgreSQL migrations with Orafce extension
  • Most Postgres contrib extensions included
Please see the Release Notes for more details about the release, Download and try it out, and we always want feedback, reply to this or message us in the #vmware-sql channel.

Data Management for VMware Tanzu v1.0 is live on Tanzu Net!
Customers can now run their own database “as a service” on vSphere for their whole organization to simplify, automate, and easily scale database provisioning and management. This release includes the following features:
  • Data services integrated include multiple versions of Postgres and MySQL v8
  • Fully automated provisioning, backups, database engine updates and security patching
  • Single node and HA deployment of database instances in just a few clicks
  • Data in transit secured with TLS
  • Restore and point-in-time restore from backups to recover from failure
  • Restrict instance creation to predefined t-shirt sizes and scale anytime as necessary
  • Monitor database health with metrics on resource utilization, database activity and usage
  • Supported platforms include vSphere 6.7 and 7
Please see the release notes for more details, download the product from Tanzu Net and try it out on your vSphere infrastructure. We look forward to your feedback. You can reply to this message or reach us on dms-pm@vmware.com.
  2 years ago
@kapte I wanted to start new thread to dig into the issue you're seeing with the proxy pods in MySQL.
  • Can you provide the events on the proxy pod with kubectl describe pod/<proxy-pod-name>
  • Can you provide mysql logs from mysql pod 0? kubectl logs pod/<mysql-pod-name>-0 -c mysql
  • You could try to connect with the mysql-healthcheck user and validate that connection is working.
  • Find the secret and decode the password: kubectl get secret <db-name>-credentials -o 'go-template={{index .data "healthcheckPassword" | base64decode}}' , just replace <db-name>
  • Access the mysql container: kubectl exec -it pod/<mysql-pod-name>-0 -c mysql -- bash
  • use healthcheck user to ping the database: mysqladmin -u mysql-healthcheck -p<password> -h localhost -P 3306 --connect-timeout=1 ping , just replace <password> and make sure there is no space between -p and the password

  12:46 PM
@channel - VMWare Tanzu SQL with MySQL for Kubernetes 1.1.0 is live on Tanzu Net! Congratulations and thanks to the following teams for the efforts involved in making this happen-
  • MySQL engineering 
  • Design
  • Technical architecture
  • Documentation 
Some of the notable features include:
  • MySQL Server 8.0.25 and Percona XtraBackup 8.0.25 support
  • Tanzu MySQL instances are now created with a version number. 
  • Users may specify the spec.version field in the instance definition to specify which Tanzu MySQL version to deploy. 
  • Users can now list instances by version number. 
  • Tanzu MySQL for Kubernetes instances now expose Prometheus compatible metrics endpoints. Metrics are secured behind a self-signed TLS certificate.
  • This release supports an additional auto-recovery feature: an HA cluster that loses quorum can now recover its state.
  • Pre-req/requirement: Tanzu MySQL for Kubernetes now requires installing Cert Manager before creating or updating new instances.
For more information, please refer to the latest release notes
12:48
@channel VMWare Tanzu SQL with MySQL for VMs 2.10.4 is available for customers! Congratulations and thanks to the following teams for the efforts involved in making this happen-
  • MySQL engineering
  • Design
  • Technical architecture 
  • Documentation 
Some of the notable features include:
  • Security fix: On Multi-Site Replication instances, the admin port on service instances has been removed. Now, Envoy only listens on the MySQL port, and multi-site instances do not have any externally available admin interfaces.
  • ApplicationDataBackupRestore (adbr) processes running on the service instances only accept TLS v1.2 connections. Previously, these adbr processes accepted all TLS connections, regardless of version.
  • Smoke test errands no longer leave orphan routes. For existing orphan routes, users can do a one-time cleanup of routes from earlier versions of Tanzu SQL with MySQL for VMs by running a series of one-time commands.
For more information, please refer to the latest release notes
  8:42 AM
Hi team, I wanted to check something with you that came out of a support case for a customer:
---------
We found that wal_keep_segments was set to 512 in their configuration.Setting wal_keep_segments back to the recommended default of ‘0’ resolved the local WAL space issues.Olivier was using an override file for the default postgresql.conf , so that was how we set  wal_keep_segments back to the default of ‘0’I’m not too sure whether wal_keep_segments=512 was set in the k8s image by default - would this be something you could find out?https://www.postgresql.org/docs/11/runtime-config-replication.html - makes clear that the default value is ‘0’.
---------
As we don’t know where the config of 512 came from, it might be worth checking if the default of 0 is actually 0 in the image. The other value led to misery quite quickly… @aberlin

  name: postgres-sample
spec:
  storageClassName: default
  storageSize: 10G
  cpu: "0.8"
  memory: 800Mi
  monitorStorageClassName: default
  monitorStorageSize: 10G
  resources:
    monitor:
      limits:
        cpu: 800m
        memory: 800Mi
      requests:
        cpu: 800m
        memory: 800Mi
    metrics:
      limits:
        cpu: 100m
        memory: 100Mi
      requests:
        cpu: 100m
        memory: 100Mi

    dbname: postgres-sample
    username: pgadmin

  2 years ago
Hi, I see Tanzu Postgresql supports full/ differential backup & restore of Postgres, are there plans to support backup & restore for specific databases or tables?
16 replies
  2 years ago
Are you referring to the K8s product?Assuming yes the answer to tis isn’t easy. You can somewhat accomplish tis today using pg_dump which is a basically a data dump and then restore only the data you are interested in. This isn’t really considered a normal or desired backup technique in Postgres because it only contains the data from that exact point in time and can’t really be updated.Another way to somewhat accomplish this is through logical replication of only the tables or DBs of interest. Usually logical replication is used for near real time replication of a subset of data.
  2 years ago
Could I ask specifically what you’re trying to do?
  2 years ago
Hi @eckhardtr thanks for the response, yes I am looking for the k8s tanzu postgresql product.
The requirement here is to backup few databases/ tables and not the entire Postgres.
  2 years ago
curiosity question, does Tanzu Postgres backup & restore works using logical replication?
  2 years ago
Why, Is there a space limitation or do you expect restore performance
  2 years ago
No, We use physical replication.
  2 years ago
Logical replication doesn’t support DDL, DML, which makes it difficult to count on
  2 years ago
physical replication ==> pg_basebackup + WAL
  2 years ago
Yes for the space constraints, and in our case, few databases/ tables can be restored directly using the application that is using it.
  2 years ago
this answers, as you are using pg_basebackup this always takes the whole cluster backup as compared to pg_dump
  2 years ago
correct.

Here's an interesting: our products are incompatible with TKGI 1.13.0 and 1.13.1 environments that are configured with the default containerd runtimeThey are using containerd 1.5.7 which includes this change released in 1.5.6. containerd then validates labels on the images and our instance images have the io.deplab.metadata label with a very large JSON string (above the 4096 length limit).
This manifests in a failure to create the container:
Error: failed to create containerd container: create container failed validation: containers.Labels: label key and value greater than maximum size (4096 bytes), key: io.deplab.: invalid argument

  1 year ago
They have like the high level steps in the 2nd case ( AKA 306385) .  I can ask them for the more detailed plan if they have one.
1. Setup a parallel Postgres cluster using Ansible scripts.
2. Setup logical replication between source and target clusters.
3. Validate that all objects have been replicated to the target cluster.
4. Schedule a cut-over date with application teams and provide connection details for the target cluster.
5. Take back of the database on the source cluster.
6. Perform a cut-over to the target cluster with application pointing there.
7. Perform application testing (performance, regression, functional testing).
8. Application team provide signoff.

#50974 crypto/elliptic: IsOnCurve returns true for invalid field elements
Guido Vranken reported to us a pair of big.Int coordinates that returns true from IsOnCurve, and then causes a panic in ScalarMult. Our investigation concluded that there is a broader issue with big.Ints that are invalid representations of a field element.BackgroundFirst, a bit of context of how we got here. crypto/elliptic implements elliptic curves over prime-order finite fields, meaning coordinates are elements of the field composed of the integers from zero to P-1 for some prime P. Integers below zero (negative) or equal to or higher than P (overflowing) are as meaningless as coordinates as float64(1.5) or string("hi") would be.Regrettably, the crypto/elliptic API allows passing negative…
Labels
Security, NeedsFix, release-blocker

Reply…
  10 months ago
The default pg_auto_failover configuration for Tanzu Postgres for K8s is single standby node architecture (1 primary node, 1 standby node), with synchronous replication between the primary and the standby node. This means that

a) All reads and writes go through the primary node.
b) At most 1 node failure can be tolerated without data loss.
c) When a node failure is detected, normally the cluster will transition to read-only mode until the standby is restored, since the standby is normally required to handle writes with synchronous replication. But, with a "single-primary-single-standby" setup, that would prevent the cluster from accepting any writes whenever any node failure is detected. This is because writes with synchronous replication normally requires 2 nodes, the primary and the standby. So, this condition is relaxed in the default config by setting number_synch_standby=0. Thus, when a node failure happens, the cluster temporarily transitions to asynchronous replication mode so that the surviving node can still accept writes, until the standby node is restored. (Failover is also disabled during this time.) Once the standby node has been detected as restored, it goes back to synchronous replication mode, meaning that the new primary cannot accept any new writes until the standby node has caught up with the primary.
d) There can be a short latency spike during the catchup period described above (between the time the healthy standby is first detected and the time it is fully caught up with the primary). The time the catchup takes depends on the network and backup strategy used. The new standby catches up by replaying the streamed WAL logs, or combining that with a fresh physical db backup if the standby lags too far behind the primary.
e) This temporary async replication window implies a small chance for data loss if the primary node is lost. It can occur during the primary node outage, as the standby node is able to accept writes without synching with the primary during this time.
f) Customers can tweak the default settings if they choose, although only the default settings are officially supported by VMware. For example, they can tweak the number_synch_standby or synchronous_commit settings.
g) The default mode enables Business Continuity rather than High Availability (i.e. at most 1 data copy is guaranteed to be consistent at a time).
(edited)

  2. kubectl logs -n <namespace> -l postgres-instance=<name-of-instance> --all-containers --max-log-requests 10 --tail=-1 --prefix
  3. The version of the operator

Hi @lixian, In your prometheus operator installation, you’ll need to set prometheus.prometheusSpec.podMonitorSelectorNilUsesHelmValues to false in order to have your PodMonitor easily discovered.This section on the postgres operator page discuss the reason in detail
  7 months ago

  7 months ago
@Lena Hunter we’ll need to update the mysql docs to include a note similar to what we have in the postgres docs
Note: In the above prometheus installation example, prometheus.prometheusSpec.podMonitorSelectorNilUsesHelmValues is set to false. It is configured to avoid the need to add a release label on each PodMonitor CR that you create.
If you already have a prometheus installation with prometheus.prometheusSpec.podMonitorSelectorNilUsesHelmValues set to true (default value), then, in order for your PodMonitor CRs to be discoverable by the Prometheus Operator, you will need to add a label release: <prometheus-release-name> to the metadata section of each PodMonitor CR that you create in the cluster. For e.g. if the helm release name is prometheus, you will add a label release: prometheus in the PodMonitor’s metadata section.

5 replies

  4 months ago

  4 months ago
I believe that is the basis of the question, yes. and if possible, any guidance further on resource allocations for different situations (if that's something that is more standard)
  4 months ago
By default, Postgres pods are deployed with the following values:Data Pod(s):
cpu: 800m
memory: 800Mi
storage: 800MB
Monitor Pod:
cpu: 800m
memory: 800m
storage: 1G
This docs page discusses how to override those default values
  4 months ago
We currently don’t have any guidance on resource allocations

VMWare Postgres versions 15.2, 14.7, 13.10, 12.14 and 11.19 are live on Tanzu Net! Thanking the following teams for the efforts involved in making this happen -
  • Postgres engineering
  • Documentation

  3:26 PM
VMware Tanzu SQL with Postgres for Kubernetes 2.1.0 and Packages for VMware Tanzu Data Services 1.8.0 (the Carvel bundles which contain 2.1.0) are live on Tanzu Net! Thanking the following teams for the efforts involved in making this happen -
  • Postgres engineering
  • Documentation
  • Release Management
Of note in this release:
  • We have enable custom user configuration of pg_hba.conf which allows for cert based auth
  • Ability to run read only queries on a remote mirror (on a DR cluster)
  • the creation of a service that allows for read only traffic to flow to the mirrors
  • Remove deprecated spec.cpu and spec.memory fields from the Postgres CRD

VMware Tanzu SQL with MySQL for Kubernetes 1.8.0 and Packages for VMware Tanzu Data Services 1.9.0 (the Carvel bundles which contain 1.8.0) are live on Tanzu Net! Thanking the following teams for the efforts involved in making this happen -
  • MySQL engineering
  • Documentation
  • Release Management
Of note in this release:
  • This release adds support for scaling high availability instances to more members.
  • Port 3307 can now be accessed on the Kubernetes service to explicitly connect to read-only members of a HA instance.
  • There is a new MySQL user named mysql-admin that can connect externally and perform administrative tasks.
  • Also, foreground cascading deletion is supported.
